metadata.title: Inferred duration of infectious period of SARS-CoV-2: rapid scoping review 1 and analysis of available evidence for asymptomatic and symptomatic 2 COVID-19 cases 3

affiliation.laboratory: Centre for Veterinary Epidemiology and Risk Analysis
Centre for Veterinary Epidemiology and Risk Analysis
Centre for Veterinary Epidemiology and Risk Analysis
Health Information and Quality Authority (HIQA), Unit 1301, City Gate, Cork

Centre for Veterinary Epidemiology and Risk Analysis

abstract.text: 18 Objectives: Our objective was to review the literature on the inferred duration of the infectious 19 period of COVID-19, caused by SARS-COV-2 virus, and provide an overview of the variation 20 depending on the methodological approach. 21 Design: Rapid scoping review. Literature review with fixed search terms, up to 1 st April 2020. Central 22 tendency and variation of the parameter estimates for infectious period in (a) asymptomatic (b) 23 symptomatic cases from (i) virological studies (repeated testing), (ii) tracing studies (iii) modelling 24 studies were gathered. Narrative review of viral dynamics. 25 Information sources: Search strategies developed and the following searched: PubMed, Google 26 Scholar, MedRxiv, BioRxiv. Additionally, the Health Information Quality Authority (Ireland) viral load 27 synthesis was utilised, which screened literature from PubMed, Embase, ScienceDirect, NHS 28 evidence, Cochrane, medRxiv and bioRxiv, HRB open databases. 29
Results: There was substantial variation in the estimates, and how infectious period was inferred. 30
One study provided approximate median infectious period for asymptomatic cases of 6.5-9.5 days. 31

Median pre-symptomatic infectious period across studies varied over <1-4 days. Estimated mean 32 time from symptom onset to two negative RT-PCR tests was 13.4 days (95%CI: 10.9-15.8), but was 33 shorter when studies included children or less severe cases. Estimated mean duration from 34 symptom onset to hospital discharge or death (potential maximal infectious period) was 18.1 days 35 (95%CI: 15.1-21.0); time to discharge was on average 4 days shorter than time-to-death. Viral 36 dynamic data and model infectious parameters were often shorter than repeated diagnostic data. 37

Conclusions: There are limitations of inferring infectiousness from repeated diagnosis, viral loads, 38 and viral replication data alone, and also potential patient recall bias relevant to estimating exposure 39 and symptom onset times. Despite this, available data provides a preliminary evidence base to 40 inform models of central tendency for key parameters, and variation for exploring parameter space 41 and sensitivity analysis. Some current models may be underestimating infectious period. 42

body_text.text: Results 191
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Overall, 65 parameter estimates were harvested from 48 papers (Tables 1, 2, 3) . 193
body_text.section: Parameter comparison 192

body_text.text: Infectious period for asymptomatic cases (T2) 194
body_text.section: Parameter comparison 192

body_text.text: The overall distributions and point estimates from studies for T2 are presented in Figure 1 and Table  195 1. 196
body_text.section: Parameter comparison 192

body_text.text: Two virological studies reported on infectious period based on serial diagnostic testing, for 197 asymptomatic cases, were found to have informative data. One of these studies reported on only 198 one asymptomatic case, with exposure to negative tests being 11 days (Zhou et al, 2020 ). This 199 duration should be considered an over-estimate, given that a latent period is not taken into 200 consideration. Hu et al. [7] tracked infections of close contacts to infected persons and considered 201 patients asymptomatic at time of diagnosis. Infectious period was defined as time from diagnosis to 202 the first of two clear tests, providing a median duration of 9.5 days (n=24) range: 1 -21; 3.5-13.0 203
body_text.section: Parameter comparison 192

body_text.text: Importantly, Hu et al. [7] found that the infectious period was different between those who 205 subsequently exhibited symptoms (i.e. pre-symptomatic) and those who did not: The median 206 duration for asymptomatic infectious was 6.0 days (IQR: 2.0 -12.0; N=19). This was reduced to 4.0 207 days (2.0 -15.0) for cases that were asymptomatic without abnormal computed tomography (CT) 208 scans (n=7). 209
body_text.section: IQR. 204

body_text.text: Two tracing studies provide informative data (Table 1; Modelling studies that have attempted to fit differing parameters depending on the severity of 218 symptoms have used differing nomenclature, for example asymptomatic, "mild" or subclinical cases 219 (Table 1) . [14, 15, 26, 27] Two papers by Davies and colleagues [14, 15] model this parameter as a 220 . body_text.text: Pan et al. [3] and Hoehl et al. [28] describe the cases of two individuals tracked and serially tested by 224 real-time reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) after being exposed to a patient 225 with confirmed infection. In the latter study, the virus was isolated from samples, indicating 226 transmission potential. 227
body_text.section: Pre-symptomatic, infectious period (T3) 223

body_text.text: Four studies from China, Germany and Singapore provide informative data through tracing infections 228 from cluster of infections, and through infector-infectee pairs ( Table 2) . [4, 9, 29 ,30] These papers There was high heterogeneity across studies (Cochrane's Q; p<0.001; I 2 >75%). A random effects (RE) 250 meta-regression model suggested significant variation depending on whether studies included 251 . Tuite et al. [26, 39] also assumed the same duration for 300 "mild" and "severe" symptomatic cases (6-6.5 days). 301 302 . body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted April 30, 2020. Hence, lower Ct values infer higher viral loads. The authors report on a patient without symptoms, 320 but with positive nasal swabs (Ct values, 22 to 28) and throat swabs (Ct values, 30 to 32) testing 321 positive on days 7, 10, and 11 after contact. Importantly, the authors suggest "the viral load that was 322 detected in the asymptomatic patient was similar to that in the symptomatic patients." 323 Furthermore, Kimbell et al. [62] report that Ct values between asymptomatic (21.9 to 31.0), pre-324 symptomatic (15.3 to 37.9), and symptomatic cases (18.6 to 29.2) within a nursing home 325 environment did not differ significantly. To et al.
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: [59] present data on temporal profile of viral load 326 from saliva samples, and found that median initial and peak viral loads in severe cases were non-327 significantly higher (p>0.5) by approximately 1 log10 higher than those in mild cases. Liu This lack of pre-symptomatic data may result in left truncation of the risk distribution associated 330 with viral load and shedding. Therefore, the typical timing of peak viral shedding (whether prior to, 331 at, or after onset), and it's impact on transmission, is still uncertain. He et al. [29] reported highest 332 viral load at symptom onset from patients sampled in a hospital in China. Furthermore, the author's 333 estimate using a separate infector-infectee dataset (n=77) that 44% (95% CI: 25-69%) of infectee 334 cases were infected during the pre-symptomatic stage of the infector. Separately, a modelling paper 335 . CC-BY 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted April 30, 2020. Wölfel et al. [50] provides important data on a cohort of nine 'mild' cases which were serially tested 339 using sputum, swabs (throat and nasopharyngeal), urine and faecal samples over time. Importantly, 340 the virus was isolated, and inferences on viral replication could be made. Viral Isolation, and insights 341 into viral replication, improve inference around viral dynamics and transmission risk. The study 342
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: suggested high viral loads shortly after symptom onset, which declined thereafter over time. Positive 343 cultures were found from day 3-8 post-symptom onset ( Figure 5 ), and the minimum 5% isolation 344 success was achieved up to 9.8 (95% CI: 8.5-21.8) days post onset from throat and lung samples but 345 not faeces, blood or urine. 346 . body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted April 30, 2020. Inferring infectiousness was challenging given the heterogeneity of evidence available. Virological 348 diagnostic studies provide robust time series of infection, however, is limited by inferring the 349 relationship between PCR diagnostics and infectiousness. These data can also be affected by 350 sampling procedure and sample sites (e.g. upper respiratory, lower respiratory, faeces, urine, blood). 351
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: We have excluded RT-PCR durations based on faecal sampling due to the uncertainty whether these 352 data pertain to transmission potential ([50]; see below). Virological studies where culturing has 353 taken place, and where viral replication can be inferred would also be considered superior data to 354 infer infectious period, relative to estimates of viral load alone. We tested the hypothesis that severity of symptoms had an effect on symptomatic infectious 367 duration using a meta-regression approach. There was a trend towards studies that included severe 368 cases tended to have longer duration (estimated to be 4.0 days longer), but the effect was not 369 significant. Some studies have reported an association between duration of infectiousness and 370 incubation time (exposure to symptom on-set; mean 7.2 days), and short serial interval (mean 6.5 375 days; median 1.9 days; time from onset in primary to onset in secondary case). 376
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: Contact tracing studies provided robust evidence of transmission events, and therefore 377 infectiousness, but can be limited by the inferred timing of events, and symptoms experienced, due 378 . body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted April 30, 2020. symptoms during the presumed asymptomatic infectious period, which included "feeling warm" and 385 "feeling cold". However, the patient only "recognized getting sick" after she returned to China on 386 day four after the presumed exposure event. 387
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: Modelling parameters provide information on how COVID-19 data are being used and interpreted in 388 the research community, given the limited data available. Posterior estimates also provide 389 information on the parameter space at which infectious period central tendency reside, given other 390 parameters and assumptions in the model. Models used highly varied approaches to modelling 391 infectious period, which in turn resulted in highly variable parameter estimates used to inform the 392 studies. 393
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: There are few data for the precise definition of the asymptomatic infectious period (T2) parameter. 395 Some reported asymptomatic cases can actually be pre-symptomatic, when cases are subject to 396 follow-up (e.g.
body_text.section: Overall duration findings 394

body_text.text: [66]; see discussion above). However, Hu et al.
body_text.section: Overall duration findings 394

body_text.text: [7] do provide the data for 397 asymptomatic cases [that remain asymptomatic] across their presumed infectious period. Therefore, 398 in the first instance a parameter mimicking their data is probably the best available data. Note, there 399 is a large variation in this data parameter, and a gamma distribution of a shape alpha 3, beta 2, mean 400 6, may be appropriate for the initial model runs. Despite these being the primary informative data, 401 caution is required, given the uncertainty around the relationship between RT-PCR results and 402 infectiousness. Overall, an informed central tendency of ~6 days, with very low probability draws for 403 durations >20 days for the T2 parameter may be considered given the current state of knowledge. 404
body_text.section: Overall duration findings 394

body_text.text: The pre-symptomatic period is sometimes referred to as 'preclinical infectious' period (parameter 405 T3). This has been estimated from several papers, and the central tendency of these estimates vary 406 from <1 -4 days, cautiously approximating to 2 days, on average. also be measured as the difference between incubation and latent period, or the difference between 410 serial interval and incubation period.
body_text.section: Overall duration findings 394

body_text.text: proportion of transmission before symptom onset (area under the curve) was estimated as 44% 442 (95% CI, 25-69%), based on inferences on incubation period. The authors suggest their data 443 supported the view that transmission risk decline substantially after 7 days post-symptoms onset. 444 . body_text.text: Overall, the studies included were of good quality, though due to the rapid need for information 459 from the global research community many papers are pre-prints that have yet to be reviewed (at 460 time of writing). Many papers were limited in terms of sample sizes, with several papers being case 461 studies of one patient or single cluster outbreaks. There was a diversity of methods employed to 462 infer dynamics of infectiousness across studies, and therefore the evidential base was variable. Some 463 issues around nomenclature were noted, including definitions of asymptomatic, infectious period, 464 latent, and incubation period. It is possible the same data may have been used across different 465 studies, especially where publicly available data were used. 466
body_text.section: Study limitations 458

body_text.text: There was significant heterogeneity across study findings, and this was related to diversity of clinical 467 findings and methods employed. The meta-analysis employed for one parameter (T5) Another limitation is that a systematic review was not undertaken to inform this research, hence 477 there is a possibility that some relevant studies were overlooked. However, comprehensive search 478 strategies were conducted by two independent research groups to inform this research, hence 479 limiting the potential for missing key studies. 480
body_text.section: Study limitations 458

body_text.text: There are few data to inform asymptomatic infectious period (T2 parameter). One study provide 482 data that suggest a median period of 4-9.5 days, however, given the viral dynamics, this distribution is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

FIGREF0.text: [7,8]). Infectious period was inferred 210 indirectly from data provided in Ma et al. [8], whereby infectious period was estimated as the 211 difference between the upper latent period estimate minus the serial interval. Ma et al. [8] reports 212 on 49 asymptomatic cases and inferred serial interval from infector-infectee pairs. Serial interval was 213 calculated by assuming "onset" was at first diagnosis. Hu et al. [7] reported on a case-study cluster 214 of infection within a house where the primary case was asymptomatic. Secondary infections 215 occurred 4-9 days after index case exposure, the index patient tested positive until day 29 post 216 exposure. 217

FIGREF1.text: 229 included the study by Rothe et al. [9], which clarified that an asymptomatic patient visiting Germany 230 from China may have actually experienced very mild symptoms around the time of transmission 231 occurred (see discussion). 232 Five modelling papers incorporated pre-symptomatic infectious period reported as prior 233 distributions or estimated as a model output. Two papers describe the prior distribution using a 234 gamma distribution.[14,15] Tindale et al. [31] provide mean point estimates under four different 235 scenarios (two populations, early and late epidemic period). Peak et al. [32] derives estimates of the 236 pre-symptomatic infectious duration from a model of serial interval, and report scenarios where 237 there are pre-symptomatic infectious periods. 238 The approximated distributions are simulated in Figure 2, which demonstrates the between-study 239 heterogeneity in this parameter. The point estimates primarily cluster around the central tendencies 240 of the distributions, except for Tindale et al. [31], for a model reporting for late occurring cases in 241 Tianjin, China (8.2 days). 242Post-symptom onset, infectious period (T5) 243The T5 parameter was informed from three lines of evidence from empirically driven studies: 244• time from symptoms onset to the first of two clear RTpresents the forest plot for the mean time from symptom onset to clearance, based on 248 serial testing meta-analysis (n=15). The mean estimated duration was 13.4 days (95%CI: 10.9-15.8). 249

FIGREF2.text: Where this has taken place, the 355 data would suggest average infectious periods of up to 9.8 days post-symptoms. Recent modelling 356 work suggest that the duration of viral detectability could overestimate the infectious period 357 somewhere between 2-6 days.[64] 358 Viral load studies suggest peak viral load occurs close to symptom onset (potentially, -1 to 7 days of 359 onset), however there is uncertainty whether this typically occurs prior to, on, or after onset (Figure 360 6 for conceptual model). High viral loads, measured as Ct values, have been recorded for one week 361 to 20 days post symptom onset, with a general decreasing trend with time. For example, To et al. 362 [59] estimates a declining slope per day for log10 RNA copies per ml of −0·15 (95% CI −0·19 to −0·11; 363 R 2 =0·71). There are some studies reporting associations between viral load and symptom severity, 364 with higher metrics of viral load in severe cases.[3,58,59] However, Zou et al. [53], and more recent 365 data from Italy,[64,65] suggest similar viral loads in symptomatic and asymptomatic cases. 366

FIGREF3.text: self-reported nature of data collection (recall bias). The subjective nature of self-reporting 379 indeed can have an impact on case definitions of 'asymptomatic', which has led to some doubt on 380 asymptomatic transmission in one case.[9] Rothe et al. [9]describe a case of apparent asymptomatic 381 transmission from a Chinese visitor to business associates in Germany, which was cast into doubt 382 when health officials reported that the patient had indeed experienced some, albeit minor, 383 symptoms.[67] Rothe et al. [9] subsequently updated the clarification of the patients self-reported 384

FIGREF4.text: 483 could have an extended tail with low probability long infectious periods of up to 20 days. The pre-484 symptomatic infectious phase (T3) is quite narrowly defined to a mean of approximately 2 days 485 (range: <1-4) within the literature. However, there is great uncertainty around the infectious period 486 from onset to recovery or death (T5 parameter). The symptom onset until clearance (based on two 487 negative RT-PCR tests) parameter estimate of 13.4 days (95%CI: 10.9-15.8) is informative for T5 488 parameter, only if one assumes that RT-PCR positive results equate to having infectious potential. 489 Many current models corral the infectious period to shorter time periods than what virological 490 studies have suggested, with one recent study suggesting that duration of viral detectability over-491 estimates the infectious period on average by 2-6 days. While viral RNA can be detected for long 492 periods of time, especially from faecal samples, the ability to isolate the virus ifrom nfected cases 493 quickly declines after one-week post-symptoms. Some modelling papers have assumed that 494 infectious period is invariant to whether cases are asymptomatic or symptomatic, however, the data 495 available are not yet rich enough to inform whether this is a good assumption. Similarly, it is not yet 496 established whether viral loads are similar between asymptomatic and mild, moderate, or severe 497 symptomatic cases, with conflicting reports in the literature. 498 Funding: All investigators are full-time employees (or retired former employees) of University 499 College Dublin, the Irish Department of Food and the Marine (DAFM), or the Irish Health Information 500 and Quality Authority (HIQA). TABREF0.text: children as part of the sample (n=15 studies; Proportion of between-study variance explained 252Adj. R 2 = 43.8%). Overall, the model estimated studies including children had on average 5.8 days 253shorter duration than adult only studies (95%CI: 1.7-10.0; p=0.040; SE(p)=0.003). A second univariate 254 RE meta-regression model suggested that there was non-significant increased mean duration of 4.0 255 days (95%CI: -0.6-8.6; p=0.111; SE(p)=0.005; Adj. R 2 = 22.0%; n=14) for studies that included 256 moderate-severe or severe cases, relative to mild or mild-moderate severity cases. 257High transmissibility during the first 5 days post symptom onset was described by Cheng et al.[33], 258 based on secondary attack rates for 12 infector-infectee pairs. No contacts (n=1043) with primary 259 cases were infected after five days of the index case onset of symptoms, inferred by the authors to 260 suggest transmission occurring at symptom onset (but conceivably also suggest pre-symptomatic 261 infection). Based on a cumulative density function, the authors suggest that infectiousness declines 262 rapidly from onset of infection (distribution was truncated at 30 days); estimated cumulative 263 For tracking studies relating to time to hospital discharge or death, raw case level data were 266 available (studies n=3).[31,34-36] Histograms of the raw data are presented in Figure 4, along with 267 the aggregated distribution. A random effect model suggested a mean duration of 18.1 days (95%ci: 268 15.1 -21.0). However, there was significant variation across studies, with time to discharge being 269 Two modelling papers use priors (mean: 3.2-3.5 days) to represent clinical infectious period.[14,15] 272 However, the distribution for this parameter is right censored when patients are hospitalised or 273 isolated and therefore not an estimate of the full infectious period per se. 274 Two tracing studies supplied parameter estimates for the full infectious period for patients who 276 develop symptoms. [8,29] He et al. [29] inferred from a publicly available dataset of 77 infector-277 infectee pairs that infectiousness began 2.3 days (95% CI, 0.8-3.0 days) prior to symptom onset, 278 peaking at 0.7 days (95% CI, −0.2-2.0 days), and continued up to 7 days from onset. The authors 279suggest that the transmission risk diminishes 7 days post symptom onset. This suggests that the 280 average infectious period, assuming a symptomatic infectious period of 7 days was approximately 281 9.3 days (7.8-10 days 95%CI, where CI is only reported for the pre-symptomatic period). He et al. 282

TABREF1.text: 25-69%). Ma et al.[8]  analysed data from a number of countries (China, Germany, Japan, Malaysia, 284 Singapore, Vietnam), collating 1155 cases from public data. They estimate several parameters, 285 including "maximum latent period" and the serial interval. The authors estimated the infectious 286 period as maximum latent period minus the serial interval. Given their parameter estimates and 287 methodological approach, infectious period would have been 5 days (range 0-24; IQR: 2-9; 288 calculated from data presented within the paper). 289Seven modelling papers reported duration of infectious period (T3+T5; Table 4), with the reported 290 central tendency for the distribution varying from 3-20 days. The form of the distribution offered to 291 models for this parameter varied considerably, including point estimates (deterministic models), flat 292 (uniform), Gaussian, Weibull and gamma distributions. Li et al. [27] estimated the shortest median 293 duration of 3.45 days, with a flat (uninformative) prior distribution corralled between 3-5 days. In 294 contrast, Zhu et al. [37] used a mean prior of 10 days, with the model estimated mean duration 295 being 12.5 days (variance 10; Weibull distribution). Piccolomini and Zama [38] used a fixed estimate 296 of 20 days infectious period, to model the Italian epidemic. Two papers from the same group [14,15] 297suggested that infectious period for asymptomatic cases approximated for symptomatic cases where 298

TABREF2.text: Viral load was reported from 21 papers using real-time reverse transcriptase polymerase chain 304 reaction (rRT-PCR) testing, generally post-symptomatic monitoring.[3,29,40-59] Qualitatively, the 305 viral dynamics described early increase in viral load, peaking around onset or within 2-4 days of 306 symptom onset (Figure 6 for a theoretical model), before decreasing gradually over the next one to 307 three weeks post symptom onset. Maximum duration of detection ranged from approximately 20-49 308 days, with the longest duration associated with faecal samples (see below for discussion). The 309 duration where ribonucleic acid (RNA) was recoverable by RT-PCR may have been truncated due to 310 insufficient follow-up in some cases. Studies that have investigated blood samples have provided 311 It should be noted the lack of data on pre-symptomatic or asymptomatic cases with regards viral 314 load. An exception was Kam et al. [61] who describe a pre-symptomatic case in an infant. In another 315 study, Zou et al. [53] undertook serial RT-PCR testing from nasal and throat swab samples from 14 316 imported cases, and 4 secondary cases, in Guangdong, China. The dynamics of the infection in terms 317 of cycle threshold (Ct) values and RNA copy number were described; Ct values of 30.76, 27.67, 31824.56, and 21.48 corresponding to 1.5×10 4 , 1.5×10 5 , 1.5×10 6 , and 1.5×10 7 copies per milliliter. 319

But uncertainty of whether this is robust remains. 371 Virological studies that included children (either mixed adult children, or children only cohorts) 372 appeared to have shorter T5 durations (estimate: 5.8 days shorter). Liao et al. [66] present data 373 which suggests that children and 'young adults' (<35 years old) infected cases exhibited long 374

TABREF7.text: The maximal reported period for 407 T3 from any population, was reported by Tindale et al. [31] at 8.2 days. Current models have used 408 central tendency estimates of 0.5 to 2.4 days.[14,15,26,39] It should be noted, that this period could 409

TABREF8.text: allows for some confidence of its distribution. Current understanding of viral dynamics of infection 412 suggest that viral load and shedding increases during post-latent phase, peaking around onset [for 413 symptomatic cases], before declining.[29,50,53] This aspect of the natural history of infection may 414 be important when attempting to model transmission dynamics. 415 Length of infectious period in symptomatic cases that do not isolate (T5 parameter) has also been 416 rarely directly measured in the literature, as serial monitoring of patients in terms of symptoms or 417 viral load (rt-PCR) generally occurs after diagnosis and/or after admission to hospital [from a 418 modelling perspective, this means cases are censored as they are assumed to no longer contribute 419 to transmission]. If natural progression of infection after diagnosis or hospital admission mimics the 420 course of infection for those who do not isolate, the review of the literature describing time to two 421 clear tests is informative. Symptom onset to serial testing clearance [assessed the time to first of two 422 RT-PCR clear tests] averaged 13.4 days (95%CI: 10.9-15.8) from our meta-analysis. In the maximal 423 case, where patients succumb or fully recover from infection, time from symptoms to death or 424 discharge may be informative. Studies that collated such information suggest mean durations of 425 18.07 days (95%ci: 15.14 -20.99), but with time to discharge being 4.96 days shorter (95%CI: 2.15-426 7.76) on average than time to death. These values may represent an over estimation of the 427 infectious period; one study suggested that there was on average 2.5 days between end of 428 infectiousness and 'removal' (recovery or death).[37] 429 Cheng et al. [33] provided evidence of transmissibility, based on attack rate from primary to 430 secondary cases, at around symptom onset. The authors estimate cumulative infectiousness from 431 onset, which suggests that 67% of total infectiousness potential occurs by the first day post-onset. 432 Most of the total infectiousness occurs within 5 days (86.9%) post onset, with the remaining 433 infectiousness potential (13.1%) being distributed up to day 30 (this truncation is an assumption by 434 the authors). It is possible that pre-symptomatic transmission occurred during this study, but the 435 authors do not estimate what proportion of transmissions occurred during a pre-symptomatic 436 infectious period, or its potential duration. 437 A model by He et al. [29] is informative for overall symptomatic duration (T3+T5), using 77 infector-438 infectee pairs where COVID-19 transmission occurred in China. The study reported that 439

TABREF9.text: Model estimates used for infectious period parameter appears to be shorter than virological studies 445 tracking RNA viral load over time. For example, Liu et al.[27] fitted a flat prior distribution for mean 446 duration (D) fixed to vary between: 2 ≤ D ≤5 days, and Lavezzo et al. [64] fixed infectious period to 2 447 days in their epidemic model; whereas viral repeat testing studies provide evidence to suggest high 448 viral loads can be detected to up 20 days [e.g. pharyngeal swabs], and potentially longer from faecal 449 samples (up to 3-4 weeks post symptoms onset). Oral-faecal transmission risk is currently unknown, 450 but some doubt has been raised about studies that have reported positive RTPCR test results (see 451 [68]; but there may be some evidence of the risk amongst children; [69]). Wölfel et al. [50] has 452 produced an important study that provides some data on viral replication, and the site and duration 453 over which this may be taking place. Their data suggests that viral replication, with high viral loads, 454 occur in the upper respiratory tract, over the first week of symptoms peaking in day 4. Virus could 455 not be isolated from faecal samples, despite high RNA concentration. Furthermore, virus was not 456 isolated from blood or urine in that study.[50] 457

TABREF10.text: using 468 virological studies, where cross study comparisons could be made, suggested that the heterogeneity 469 was high. Fu et al.[70] cautions against combining studies to give an overall estimate without 470 exploring subgroup or meta-regression analysis, which we have done here. The meta-regression was 471 based on a small number of studies (n=12-13). Cochrane's handbook suggests 10 studies for each 472 level of a meta-regression, however in practice much lower numbers have been used to test 473 hypotheses [22], as is the case here. Fu et al. [70] recommend a minimum of 4 studies per category, 474 and therefore we dichotomised our predictor variables to ensure we met this minimum. Aggregating 475 our categories resulted in crude findings. 476
